audited_claims.strategic_fit_assessment: This is an aspirational goal statement, not a description of functional optimization. No specific process improvement or efficiency gain is described.
audited_claims.evidence_quality_assessment: Vague metric without methodology or baseline. 'Improve lives' is not measurable in operational terms.
audited_claims.notes: Marketing statement rather than operational capability case. Lacks specificity about how AI optimizes existing functions.

audited_claims.strategic_fit_assessment: Describes optimization of diagnostic and treatment planning processes - clear functional improvements in healthcare delivery.
audited_claims.evidence_quality_assessment: Claims are general without specific metrics. 'Significantly reduce human error' is unquantified. Source appears to be AWS case study which may have marketing bias.
audited_claims.notes: Clear process optimization but lacks quantified evidence. Single-vendor case study requires additional verification.

audited_claims.strategic_fit_assessment: Clear description of workflow optimization and productivity improvement - classic Tier 1 functional enhancement. Pattern is replicable across healthcare organizations.
audited_claims.evidence_quality_assessment: Specific processes identified (data consolidation, workflow streamlining, productivity increase). Named organization with traceable source.

apqc_functions.name: Develop and manage IT resilience and risk

audited_claims.notes: Strong Tier 1 case describing operational efficiency gains through data integration and workflow optimization.

audited_claims.strategic_fit_assessment: Describes capacity optimization through automation - fits Tier 1 pattern of doing existing work more efficiently.
audited_claims.evidence_quality_assessment: Specific metric (double capacity) but presented as potential/projection rather than achieved result. 'Could potentially' indicates speculation rather than demonstrated capability.

apqc_functions.name: Develop and manage human resources planning, policies, and strategies

audited_claims.notes: Compelling efficiency claim but speculative nature weakens evidence quality. Needs verification of actual vs. projected results.

audited_claims.strategic_fit_assessment: Identifies specific inefficiency in data access processes - establishes baseline for optimization. Quantifies time waste that AI could address.
audited_claims.evidence_quality_assessment: Highly specific metrics (45 minutes per shift, 23 days per year). References FHI report providing authoritative source.
audited_claims.notes: Strong evidence establishing the efficiency problem that AI solutions address. Provides quantified baseline for measuring improvement.

audited_claims.strategic_fit_assessment: Describes patient outcomes from system delays but doesn't describe AI optimization or functional improvement.
audited_claims.evidence_quality_assessment: While specific and well-sourced, this claim establishes a problem rather than describing an AI capability solution.
audited_claims.notes: Problem statement rather than capability case. Doesn't describe how AI optimizes existing functions - just identifies the issue to be solved.

tier_verification: Correctly classified as tier 1. Claims focus on optimizing existing healthcare delivery functions rather than creating new business models. No evidence of tier 1 business model transformation.
